dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet upper-middle class neighborhood. The CAMERA is at the curb, looking down the street. There are no sidewalks Trees arch overhead. CICADAS drone on the soundtrack. The OPENING TITLES briefly FADE IN and OUT, framed by the trees on either side of the street. Footsteps are heard  approaching. As the picture TITLE FADES, out of the dark emerges a GIR 17 years old, carrying schoolbooks. This is JILL. CAMERA  PANS with her ninety degrees as she comes to the front of house and stops. Lights are on in the bottom half of the house, and the  curtains across the windows are open. A single light burn in the upper right side of the house, presumable in a bed but the curtains in the room are drawn. A scene TITLE appears on the lower half of the screen: 8 pm Tuesday, March 23, 1971

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TITLE FADES, and Jill heads up the walk to the front  door of the house. The light in the upper floor of the house is turned off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged DOCTOR is standing at the foot of the stair His WIFE is descending the stairs, putting on her earring She is in an obvious hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only called her ten minutes ago --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passing into living  room) I made our reservation for 8:15.  We're going to be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here she is now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to the front door and opens it. The girl smile at him uncomfortably from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Minakis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandrakis. It's okay. Everyone gets  it wrong the first time. You're Jill?  Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wife comes back into the front hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've written the number of the  restaurant on the notepad by the  phone. (to Doctor) Zip me up, will you please? (to Jill) If we aren't home in two hours, it  means we've decided to go on to a  movie and won't be back until after  midnight. Is that all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helping wife on with  her coat) I've told my service to pick up any  calls coming in to my office phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are asleep upstairs --  first door on your left at the top  of the landing. They're both just  getting over a cold -- so try not to  wake them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to go now. We're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross to the front door and begin to exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make yourself at home. The  refrigerator's loaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling doctor through  the door) Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor pokes his head back through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We even have some low-fat yogurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you please come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor pulls the door shut behind him. Jill turns tow the living room. Pause. She walks into the living room an sets her books down on a table with the telephone on it. O.S. we hear the car doors close, the engine start up, th the car backing out the driveway and heading down the str

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dark. O.S. we hear the phone in the living room bei lifted off its receiver, a dial tone, then a number is di Pause, then ringing. CAMERA SLOWLY DOLLIES from the dinin room, across the front hall and into the living room wher we see Jill talking over the phone to a girlfriend, NANCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Jill? How's it going? (out of phone) I got it, Dad! (beat) Father! (into phone again) Jesus Christ! My father's in one of  his moods again. Male menopause, you  know. So how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you over at Dr. Mandrakis'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I've been here for about an  hour already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it a neat house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess... I haven't looked around  very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see his kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they were asleep when I got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're really cute. So what can I  do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't happen to talk to Billy  today, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I talked to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say anything about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you did to him, or  said to him, or what... but he's  really pissed off at you! What did  you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what I didn't do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Yeah, I can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me a favor, Nance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you'll be talking with  Billy some time tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prabably. I'm going to the library  in a few minutes. I just have to get  out of this house! (beat) Hey! Why don't Billy and I come over  there? He'll come along if I tell  him to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That isn't what I had in mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be safe with Billy. I'll be  there. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy, all you want to do is come  over here and get drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking) Who? Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see Billy, don't you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a lot of work to do. I don't  want you coming over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what your problem is, Jill,  is you're so straight. I really mean  that. You go to a private school,  you wear a bra. No one can have a  good time with you! (beat) You know, Billy asked me to go out  with him this weekend, and I was  really really tempted because I like  Billy... a lot... as much as you do.  But I told him I couldn't, that I  didn't think it was right because  you were my friend --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, just give Billy the number  here, but don't tell him I told you  to. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I've got to go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Nancy. Bye. And thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill makes a face at the phone and hangs up. She tries to back to her homework, but she cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill is working now, diligently. The phone rings. She pic it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a brief pause; then the line goes dead and a dia tone cuts in. Jill hangs up and goes back to work. Pause. The phone rings again. Jill picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VOICE speaks on the other end of the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you checked the children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line goes dead. Dial tone. Jill hangs up and goes rig back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill sits at the table as before, doing her homework, smo a cigarette. The phone rings. Jill picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you checked the children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mandrakis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line goes dead. Dial tone. Jill hangs up and looks of into space, thinking. O.S. we hear a faint rattling noise from somewhere in the house. Jill hears it too. She stubs out her cigarette, ge up from the table and walks out of the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill enters the hallway and pauses. Then she starts walki slowly down the hall to the kitchen door. Again the rattling noise O.S., only louder this time. Jil stops dead, listens, then continues forward even more  cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jill enters. She cannot find the lightswitch, so she s in the darkness listening. Again the rattle, very close n Jill turns her head sharply, then walks to the refrigerat and opens it. It is only the automatic icemaker creating rattle. Jill takes a piece of cake from the refrigerator and leav the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill is sitting at the table, polishing off the cake. The the phone rings. Jill stands up quickly and picks up the  phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you checked the children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy! I don't think this is very  funny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. "Billy" doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line goes dead. Jill stands frozen beside the table w the phone in her hand as the dial tone gets louder and lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill is standing at the wet bar in the corner, pouring he a drink. She samples the alcohol, doesn't cough, and star to pour a little more into the glass. The phone rings. Jill turns, then slowly walks to the tab kneels down and quietly picks up the phone and brings it her ear. She waits and listens, a full three seconds. No  sound comes to her. She quickly hangs up the phone before the silence can be  broken by the voice she knows is waiting on the other end Then, she shuffles through her books and papers on the ta top until she finds the notepad the doctor's wife has lef for her with the name and phone number of the restaurant. Jill picks up the phone and dials. After several rings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Golden Bull...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, I'd like to speak to Dr.  Mandrakis. This is his babysitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill waits for several seconds until the Maitre D' comes  back on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Mandrakis left the restaurant  about forty minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Okay. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up, thinks for a moment, then picks up the phon again and dials "O"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Operator...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Operator? Can you get me the  police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this an emergency?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! (beat) No, not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number is 555-9431. Would you  like me to connect you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventh Precinct, Sergeant Sacker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, I've been getting phone calls,  every fifteen minutes or so. I think  it's a man. He's trying to scare me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An anonymous caller?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he threatened you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he been using obscene language?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He just keeps calling me.  Sometimes he doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's really nothing we can do  about it down here. Is the phone  listed in your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm just the babysitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably just some weirdo. The  city's full of them. Believe it or  not, we get reports like this every  night. It's nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you tried whistling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can find a good loud whistle  somewhere in the house, blow it into  the phone hard, next time he calls.  Probably break his eardrum. He won't  bother you after that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I... You're probably right. It's  nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or you could just take your phone  off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the people I'm babysitting for  might try to reach me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as I say, there's nothing we  can really do to help you down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet. Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill hangs up. After thinking for a moment, she tries a c of ways of whistling as loud as she can, but frustrated a feeling foolish, she soon gives up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill is sitting in an armchair facing the TV set. The TV on, but she is bored. She runs through several channels,  then gets up and turns the TV off. She looks around and moves aimlessly back to the table, b O.S. a dog is barking and she is drawn to the window. A c passes outside, its lights reflecting off the window and  Jill's face. Then the phone rings. Jill moves quickly from the window the table and answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why haven't you checked the children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned, Jill hangs up the phone. She turns and goes slow back to the window. She pulls the shutters closed in fron of the window. Then she walks out of the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill goes to the front door, turns the bolt and draws the chain across the door. Then she starts to go upstairs. The phone rings. She stops halfway up the stairs. She tur and comes back down the stairs to answer the phone, but t thinks better of it. She sits on the bottom step and lets the phone ring and ring... Finally, it stops. Jill gets up and heads into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill goes to the table, picks up the phone and dials...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventh Precinct, Sergeant Sacker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called you before... about the man  who keeps calling me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He called me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you try whistling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's out there somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the neighborhood. He's been  watching me... through the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I know he's there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the house locked up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the windows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're safe. If he wanted to  break in, he wouldn't be calling  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, can't you help me? I'm all  alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what. If this guy calls you  again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will call again! I know he will!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, calm down now. I can alert the  phone company so that if he calls  again we can try to trace the call.  What's your number there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3317 Oakridge Drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I know where that is. All  right. If the guy calls again, try  to keep him on the line for at least  a minute so we can trace the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he never stays on that long!  Sometimes he hangs up after just a  couple of seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only way we can help you. (beat) By the way, what's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill, the important thing is to relax.  You're safe where you are. We've got  patrolmen cruising the area all night  long. Just stay calm. Will you do  that for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the meantime, we'll be watching  your line. Okay, Jill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call again if there's any problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill hangs up the phone and looks forlornly off into spac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill is sitting on the sofa, a drink in one hand, a cigar in the other. She is waiting. She sets her glass down, st out the cigarette, leans back and sighs. She is very tens Then the phone rings. She rises from the sofa and slowly  crosses to the table. She sits down and picks up the phon During this conversation it becomes apparent that the VOI has a slight English accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be here much longer. The  doctor and his wife are coming home  soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning toward the  window) I'm sorry I turned the lights down.  It didn't work anyway. I can turn  them back up if you like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't? (beat) You've really scared me. Is that  what you wanted? (beat) Is that what you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your blood... all over me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Jill is terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know me. You don't know  who I am or where I live. I'll get  Dr. Mandrakis to drive me home. Him  or the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've called the police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Jill searches for some way of answering him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line goes dead. Jill hangs up. She stands. She starts shake. The phone rings and Jill snatches it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill, this is Sergeant Sacker! Listen  to me! (beat) We've traced the call. It's coming  from within the house. A squad car's  on its way over there now... just  get out of that house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill hangs up. She stands frozen in shock. Several second go by. She doesn't move. Then the phone rings. She turns and tiptoes toward the fr door. Halfway there, the phone stops ringing. She pauses a second, then continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill reaches the front door. Carefully, quietly, she turn the bolt. Then O.S. she hears a creak. She turns and look up the staircase. At the top, a door is opening. Someone coming out! A mumbling sound is heard on the sound track. Jill whirls around back to the door and yanks at it. It o but only an inch. The chain is still across it! She  frantically works to get the chain free. After agonizing  seconds, the chain falls clear and the door swings open. Standing there on the other side of the door, is a police Detective, JOHN CLIFFORD. (We have cut ahead in time some twenty or thirty minutes.) Behind him on the street, seve patrol cars and an ambulance are pulled up at the curb, t domelights silently flashing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are the parents here yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, they arrived about ten minutes  ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ! (beat) What a homecoming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wanted to talk to someone. I  asked them to wait until you got  here. Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford sighs and steps into the front hall. The door is closed by the uniformed COP with whom Clifford has been  speaking. The cop is a man in his thirties. His name is  CHARLES GARBER. Garber and Clifford stand in the front ha and talk as POLICEMEN and AMBULANCE ATTENDANTS move aroun them. In the living room beyond can be seen several other POLICEMEN, Dr. Mandrakis and his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were only a block away when the  call went out. When we got here, the  guy was still waiting upstairs in  the children's bedroom. He was covered  with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not his own. The children had been  dead for several hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd been using an old phone in their  bedroom that the parents had never  had disconnected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found a Merchant Seaman's card on  him. He's English. Entered the country  less than a week ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about the babysitter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's going to be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Garber delivers his final line, we see ambulance atten dressed in white, taking a sheet-covered stretcher out th front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An upper-class neighborhood. The CAMERA is facing down th street. A car approaches the intersection at the end of t block, turns and comes slowly up the street. Because it is not a new car or an expensive car, and beca it is moving at a rate which suggests that its sole male  occupant is looking for house numbers, we can assume that the DRIVER is a visitor to this neighborhood. The CAMERA PANS with the car ninety degrees as it turns i the semi-circular driveway of a mansion and rolls up to t front door. A TITLE appears across the bottom of the screen: 4:30 pm Thursday, April 20, 1978

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the TITLE FADES, the driver shuts off the car engine a opens the door to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings. A HOUSEBOY comes into the front hall, goes to the door and opens it for the visitor. It is John Clifford, the detective from six years ago. He has aged noticeably over the years. His hair is grayer his stance not so aggressive, but his eyes still smoulder with the accumulated frustration of having spent years in uncertain, sometimes unsatisfying, and frequently unsafe  occupation. No words are exchanged as the houseboy leads Clifford acr the entrance hall and up an imposing flight of stairs. St keen in his observation of things, Clifford quickly takes this new atmosphere. The house is richly decorated but with an underlying them of melancholy. There are no bright or cheerful furnishing and the houseboy advances with guarded tread, his face st and reverent. The houseboy stops before a door at the top of the stairc and raps lightly on it with his knuckles. Without waiting for an answer, he opens the door and steps aside for Clif to enter. Clifford pauses briefly, then walks into what appears to an upstairs study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN is sitting behind a desk which faces the door.  Presumably he is the master of the house. Although his fa is hidden in shadows, we can see from his hands that he i engaged in writing something down. Clifford quietly approaches the desk and takes a seat in  front of it. Then, vaguely in keeping with the spirit of house, he waits to be spoken to rather than interrupt the pervasive stillness. After a moment, the master of the house lays down his pen and leans back in his chair. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're in business for yourself  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Yes, sir, for the past three and a  half years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. (beat) And you'd heard about Curt Duncan's  escape?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think the police will... find  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know they haven't assigned anyone  to it specifically. It's an old case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a tinge of bitterness) An old case. (beat) Can you find him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Maybe not tomorrow, maybe not  this week, but I'll find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could be anywhere by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so... because he's a  foreigner. He'll come back to the  city. After six years in confinement,  it's the only place that's familiar  to him. That's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man murders two children in cold  blood. A jury declares him insane.  How could such a person not be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford lowers his eyes, doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is sent to a state mental  institution where the security is...  less than perfect. And he escapes.  It... it isn't fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The master of the house leans way forward over his desk, his face comes out of the shadows and into the light. It Dr. Mandrakis. He seems much older. His complexion is pallid. His eyes s out from beneath his brow like a wounded animal hiding in dark cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thing like that should never be  allowed to happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't agree with you more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other for a long moment of acknowledgme Then Mandrakis stands up with a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead then. My accountant will  contact you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford stands and they shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (beat) How is Mrs. Mandrakis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is... unable to have any more  children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Please give her my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford turns to go. INT. MANSION - STAIRCASE & ENTRANCE HALL As Clifford finds his own way down the stairs and out the front door. A WOMAN watches Clifford leave from the back of the stair It is Mrs. Mandrakis. As with her husband, the change in is remarkable. She is now a brooding, barren woman. O.S. the front door closes. Clifford is gone. Mrs. Mandra walks around the front of the stairs and begins slowly  ascending them. The houseboy silently steps into the entrance hall from a side door and watches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A male PATIENT wearing green, institutional pajamas and  slippers shuffles slowly up the hall. His movement is  catatonic, unfocused. Canned Musak faintly underscores the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curt Duncan isn't going to run right  out and kill more children. I'm not  worried about that.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: Standing in the doorway of an office, facing into the hal watching the patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had him for six years... under  continuous therapy, some of it rather  forceful...

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT
dialogues.text: Moving past CAMERA. He is really out of it. It is a  depressing, vaguely unnerving sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and drugs... tranquilizers  depressants, lithium...

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: He turns and goes back into the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see now the MAN who's been talking -- the director of State Hospital, DR. MONK. He is sitting comfortably behin his desk; his jacket off, his tie loosened, his feet up o the desk. He is very matter-of-fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eventually, anyone will respond to  the treatment here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford sits down in front of the desk, picks up a folde and leafs through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave him electric shock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we zapped him a few times.  It's fairly standard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says here thirty-eight... thirty- eight times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monk shrugs, then yawns expansively. He needn't justify  himself to the layman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will happen to him now, without  the drugs he was on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. MONK'S SECRETARY enters the office and hands him a fo Without interrupting the delivery of his lines, Monk take the folder, opens it, initials something on the inside, c the folder and hands it back to the secretary who turns a leaves the office without uttering a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There'll be some deterioration. That's  inevitable, but we can't say how  much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Clifford looks at the doctor as if questioning his casual assessment of "some deterioration."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the time that you had him  here, did you discover any particular  habits of his, peculiarities, quirks,  anything that might help me find  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging again) It's all in the folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any letters from people back in  England? Family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That, too, is in the folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford directs a bleak look back down at the open folde then looks up again, his eyes narrowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get something straight here,  Doctor. I've been 33 years in the  business of tracking people down and  putting them away. I spent almost a  year on Curt Duncan alone, with the  trial, the testimonies, the background  investigations. I didn't come here  today to look in your goddamn folders.  In fact, I wouldn't have come here  at all if you'd done your job right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clifford, this is a hospital,  not a penitentiary. Everything that  pertains to one of our patients is  meticulously recorded in that  patient's folder... whether you can  make sense of it or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They glare at each other for several seconds. Monk is the first one to look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curt Duncan is a classic paranoid- schizophrenic. They see themselves  as victims, and they always blame  other people for the way they are.  When Duncan killed the Mandrakis  kids, it wasn't an act of hostility  against the children but against  their parents. He was getting back  at his own parents for traumas he  suffered in early childhood. The  criminal side of Curt Duncan is one  of terrible, symbolic vengeance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) Assuming he isn't found right away...  what will happen to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monk rises and walks to a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'll find him. Somebody  will find him. He can't function out  there. He'll make a mistake. (turning to face  Clifford) This is where he belongs. After six  years in here, he's suddenly gone  out to confront the world again. I  think he's in for a bit of a shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monk looks back out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a terribly good section of town. We are looking at th nondescript exterior of a bar across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a slum bar, but it's close. There are a few t and chairs and a pool table in the back. The atmosphere i quiet, almost depressed, and the handful of REGULARS here are exercising their privacy without having to be alone. They include: HANK, the bartender, also the owner, who  absently polishes things with his cloth; TRACY, an unempl woman in her mid-forties who sits at the bar with a drink and a cigarette and silently rummages through her current feelings -- none of them new or particularly hopeful; a  COUPLE, probably retired, sitting at the same table they  come to every afternoon at this time -- him for his beer, her for a glass of sweet white wine; and BILL, at the poo table, a young man lithe and powerful, minding his own  business and playing his game of pool with a steady,  aggressive concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rackin' 'em up today, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder) Doin' all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man smiles stupidly around the room. He racked 'e up a little in his day, too. His smile fades as he looks his wife. He takes a sip of beer and lapses into memories Then the door opens to the outside and the yellow-orange  light of late afternoon floods into the bar. The regulars turn to glimpse who's coming in. They see the figure of a MAN silhouetted in the doorway. He stands there for a lon moment, not coming in. Finally even Bill interrupts his g to turn and look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon in and shut the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The intruder enters, indecisively. The door swings shut b him, plunging the room back into darkness. This man is "a little weird", and the regulars continue to stare at him  until he makes his way to a table near the wall and sits  down. Then everyone returns to his own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) What'll it be? (pause, no answer) Hey! What'll it be?

dialogues.speaker: INTRUDER
dialogues.text: A bit startled, a bit defensive toward the directness of  this question. It is Curt Duncan. He looks understandably harried. He hasn't slept or shaved in at least a couple o days, and is wearing regular clothing. He clears his throat to answer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of clothes was he wearing...  when he escaped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford is looking through the folder again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ordinary street clothes. Not all of  our patients have to wear the green  Gucci gowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he have any money with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably. But not more than, say,  fifty dollars. Some of the patients  are given little jobs around the  ward, for which they are paid. It's  part of the rehabilitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down, Clifford pauses over a page in the folder.

dialogues.speaker: FACT SHEET IN FOLDER
dialogues.text: A page of legibly organized facts and statistics about Cu Duncan. One of the entries reads: Guy du Marraux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) What's Guy du Mar--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pronouncing it  correctly) Guy du Marraux syndrom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a psycho-motor dysfunction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan had it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only from time to time, which is  unusual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It attacks the nervous system. People  suffering from it are irresistibly  compelled to utter obscenities,  sometimes one, sometimes a whole  string of them. They can't control  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat taken aback) Are you being serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Here, I'll give you an example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens a file cabinet drawer, finds a reel of quarter-i magnetic tape and starts to thread it through a recorder his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan never had the twitch that  sometimes goes with it. And with  Duncan, as I said, the disease would  only manifest itself in periods of  extreme anxiety. When he was really  flipping out, in other words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause as Monk fiddles with the tape recorder a Clifford looks back down at the folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan was Catholic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (beat) So am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly surprised) That makes three of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right? So we all share the  same guilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford smiles. Monk keeps fiddling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. This is Curt Duncan shortly  after he was admitted here in 1972.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monk turns on the tape recorder as Clifford sits forward his chair to listen. At first, nothing can be heard. Then there is a click as the machine was turned on in the middle of a conversation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- to put the situation right. The  hypodermic needles are only used to  give you medication that will calm  you down. They make you feel good,  relaxed. All right? (no answer) We're not putting anything in your  food either. The food is just food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extremely agitated) No. I don't eat the food. It doesn't  taste right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Clifford) That's Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford nods and keeps listening:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curt, why are you fidgeting? Can't  you get comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not comfortable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a -- Hey! (to someone else) Hold him down there. Grab him! Never  mind the chair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are scuffling noises underneath which can be heard, heavy breathing and then, getting louder and more furious Duncan falling into the throes of Guy du Marraux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (periodically  interjecting) Pull him down... That's right...  Just lay him out... Lay him right  out... Steady... Pull out his knees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally Monk is heard no more and Duncan continues with t frightening verbal torrent of Guy du Marraux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting at his table inside the bar. He takes a long, noi drink from what looks like a bourbon on the rocks. It tas good, being the first real drink he's had in over six yea But Duncan cannot relax enough to enjoy it fully. His eye are ever restlessly, suspiciously moving about.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: As Bill walks up and stands next to Tracy. Hank moves off get Bill another beer. Tracy looks up at Bill and smiles. As regulars at the sam bar, they are loose and comfortable with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) A little action for your game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) What, him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both turn and look across the room at Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: As Bill and Tracy look straight at him over their shoulde and then turn back.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: As they both smile at her joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't bet against you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? You don't like me  playing with myself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy grimaces as Hank comes back with Bill's beer. Bill  picks up the bottle, nods his thanks to Hank and heads ba to the pool table.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: As his eyes follow Bill to the pool table, then come back Tracy at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Looking at the back of Tracy. She reaches into her purse.

dialogues.speaker: ON TRACY
dialogues.text: She takes her pack of cigarettes from the purse. She pull out a cigarette, taps it lightly on the bar, puts it to h lips. O.S. we hear the sound of a match being struck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan is standing beside her holding a lit match. He sho it forward at her. It goes out. Duncan fumbles for another match as Tracy regards him wit undisguised repulsion. Duncan gets the second match lit a holds it out for her. She accepts the favor and lights he cigarette. Duncan smiles. Tracy nods and turns away. Duncan is still holding the burning match for her to blow out. As it does look like she's going to, he lets it drop, still lit, to floor.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: He gives a look as if to say, "Jesus, what a fuckin' weir

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN AND TRACY
dialogues.text: Pause. Duncan is still smiling at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you been up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at him) My own business. (beat) Thanks for the light. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Englishman sits down beside her, but doesn't look at  her. Tracy looks away too, determined to ignore him, not to le him get into her space. Duncan coughs. After a long moment, he turns back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next round's on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy keeps her eyes straight ahead, acknowledging nothin Pause. Duncan takes some money from his pocket and lays it on th bar, staring at her. Tracy turns to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Listen, mister, I've got my own money.  So, if you don't mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks away again. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After what I been through, I don't  mind anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Longer pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, that's the whole point. My  mind... Your mind... Where do they  fit in? You know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy abruptly picks up her purse and moves down the bar  away from him one seat, then another seat.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY COUPLE
dialogues.text: They are watching this little spectacle with growing  curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Still looking at her. By pointing at what she has, he ord two more drinks from the Bartender. When they arrive, he  takes a big swallow from one, picks up the other, stands, moves down the bar and sits beside Tracy again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (setting her drink  before her) Do you live around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get offa me!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even Bill now looks up from the pool table. His expressio darkens.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Tracy has clammed up -- her elbows on the bar, head betwe her elbows, arms covering her ears, hands clasped behind neck. Duncan looks at her nervously and starts to talk ag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rapidly) Listen, I didn't mean nothin'. I  don't live around here. See -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the lady wants to be left  alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan looks up. Bill enters the frame and stands in fron of Tracy, confronting Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Looking up at Bill, his eyes red, his gaze unsteady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air is charged with tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think an apology is in order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan doesn't know how to handle this. He looks at Bill, half shrugs, half smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That the best you can do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan looks away. A long moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd better just move along,  pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan doesn't move, says nothing. He swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be okay now, Bill. He just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I want him out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender steps back, deciding to mind his own busine Tracy gets up from her seat and cautiously moves even fur down the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Duncan) Go on, beat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They glare at each other. The longer Duncan sits there wi moving, without saying anything, the angrier Bill gets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the tension builds.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Duncan looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to say it again, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan reaches for his drink, but Bill reacts quicker. Wi a swipe of his hand, he knocks the glass off the bar, and shatters on the floor behind the bar. Duncan sits there, stunned, not looking up. After a long  moment, Duncan coughs. Then he turns and looks at Bill. H purses his lips. It looks like a nervous facial movement. Then suddenly, Duncan spits at Bill, hitting him square i the face. Before anyone can register what's happened, Bill lunges a Duncan, knocking him clean off the barstool and onto the  floor. The fight is fast, vicious and one-sided from the very st Pinned to the floor on his back, Duncan flails his arms  ineffectually like a panicked insect as Bill holds him in place with a left-handed grip on the collar while his pow right arm, pumping up and down like a piston, pounds into Duncan's face time and time again. Duncan's screams diminish into pathetic, sickening groans and the others in the bar are compelled to avert their ey from this brutal spectacle. Hank has picked up a phone from beneath the bar and is di a number. He turns away from the fight to talk. Then, as suddenly as Bill first sprang at Duncan, he leap to his feet and turns to the bar. He reaches over and gra the phone from Hank, slamming it down into the cradle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who're you calling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill takes the cloth from the bar and vigorously wipes hi face off. He snaps his fingers and points to a row of bot on a shelf behind the bar. Hank quickly hands him a bottl Bill pours himself a shot and downs it, fast. He is still charged with adrenaline and he takes two more shots in ra succession, spilling the alcohol on the bar and on himsel As Bill picks up the cloth to wipe himself off again, Tra stands up and quickly walks out of the bar, slamming the  door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after her) You're welcome, baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he throws down the cloth, picks up the bottle, turns and, standing over Duncan's inert form, empties half the  bottle onto him. He sets the bottle back on the bar. He g Duncan and, half dragging, hurries him out the back door throws him into the alley where Duncan falls in a heap. Bill storms back up to the bar and pours himself another  drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hank) Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank just looks at him, doesn't answer. At the wife's sil insistence, the elderly couple stand up to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good riddance to bad rubbish, eh,  Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill doesn't answer and the couple quietly leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetic) A fight breaks out, there's gonna be  damages. Insurance company doesn't  pay without a police report...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see any damages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank lowers his gaze to the floor. Bill finishes his drin He is still very hopped up. He pulls a few dollars from h wallet and drops them on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ya 'round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and strides out of the bar. CAMERA HOLDS for a beat on Hank alone now in his empty  establishment. The phone starts to ring, presumably the p calling back. After several rings, Hank picks up the phone and listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) No, it's over now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the lights are out inside the house, but we should ju be able to see that we are in the hall, looking at the fr door. Footsteps approach on the walk outside. A key slips into the lock... Inside the house we can hear faint whispering. Someone is moving about in the darkness. Then the door swings open a the shadowy figure of a MAN crosses the threshold. He sto just inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Donna. Donna! Hey! (under his breath) What the hell -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the lights come on and a chorus of voices cry ou

dialogues.speaker: "SURPRISE
dialogues.text: A broad smile breaks across the man's face. We may recogn him as the cop from six years ago -- Charles Garber. Toda he is a lieutenant on the force and dresses casually for  work, usually in slacks, turtleneck and jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely surprised) What is all this?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garber looks sheepishly at his hand holding the pistol he drawn just before the lights came up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shoot us, Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chagrined) How was I supposed to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody starts to laugh, including Garber as he returns the pistol to his shoulder holster.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Garber's wife. She comes out of the kitchen carrying a  birthday cake with lit candles and makes her way through crowd of GUESTS singing "Happy Birthday". Everyone joins in as Donna moves forward and stands besid her husband. Clifford is one of the guests. He has his ar around a young BLOND who is sort of pretty despite her  tacky/plastic appearance. When the song is over, Garber blows out the candles and h and kisses his wife. Everybody cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is still in full swing. Garber is following Cli up the stairs. They are both fairly loaded by now. Garber, in particular, has reached that stage of inebriat where standing still is pretty hard to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you tell me what this is about,  Cliff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I can take any more of  these surprises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clifford and Garber enter. Garber turns on a light as  Clifford closes the door, shutting out the sounds of the  party below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay now, what's the big deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand still. I want you to remember  this in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want me to remember something  in the morning, then tell it to me  in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garber half comically turns to go. Clifford stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, come on.

dialogues.speaker: CORNER OF BEDROOM
dialogues.text: A BABY between a year and two years old is lying in a cri It opens its eyes and starts looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right. What is it?  You're getting married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I got a job today, tracking  someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT - CLIFFORD & GARBER Garber, still moving restlessly, pats his friend on the  shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great, Cliff; I'm sure you'll  find your man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Curt Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garber stops suddenly, stunned. In an instant, he has bec stone sober.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BABY
dialogues.text: Kicking and wiggling about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't know he got out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby opens its mouth and starts to cry. TWO SHOT - CLIFFORD & GARBER Garber glances over his shoulder at the baby, then turns  back to Clifford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your cooperation on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is late. The block is virtually deserted. Across the s is the exterior of a bar -- the same bar Duncan was in  earlier. Some PEOPLE are coming out of the bar. It must b near closing time. The people turn left and walk away dow the sidewalk. Their voices diminish. Pause. A car passes. Then the door to the bar opens again and a  woman comes out onto the sidewalk. It is Tracy. She turns the right and starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: He is standing in shadows across the street, watching her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of shots of Tracy walking home. The CAMERA remai consistently behind her or off to one side, sometimes DOL with her behind a row of parked cars, sometimes picking u her passing reflection in a darkened store window. The impression this gives is unmistakable. Curt Duncan is following her. We do not see him, we do not hear him, yet know he is there. Often we can sense that the very angle  from which we see Tracy is his POV. But Tracy is aware of nothing. We know this when the CAME begins to move in front of her, once more becoming an  impersonal observer of her walk homeward, to safety. Tension mounts as we start to expect that Duncan will jum out at her from every alley and recessed doorway she pass But he doesn't. Finally, Tracy walks up to the CAMERA at the end of a blo and turns a corner; but the CAMERA HOLDS on the dark stre she has just come up. We hear a cough which confirms that Duncan is lurking somewhere in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy walks up the steps and enters the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy steps into the elevator. The doors close. CAMERA HO on the elevator and watches the lights above it travel fr one to six. O.S. we hear the door to the apartment building open and  close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy steps out of the elevator and walks down the hall t her door. She fumbles through her purse for keys, then be over the lock to let herself in. Behind her down the hall, Duncan appears. He watches her, starts to move silently forward. Tracy gets the door open then turns and sees him. Duncan stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's you! (beat) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving forward) ...Came to apologize. I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm the one who should be sorry.  I didn't want that to happen. (she sees his face;  shudders) Oh, God! Look at you. Are you all  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan half shrugs, half smiles. Tracy edges into her doo way. Duncan stands opposite her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm new in town. Don't know anybody...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Where're you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coughs) New York. Ever been there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Sure I've been there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other. Duncan coughs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of a mean place to be. Everyone  cold, unfriendly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside Tracy's apartment, the telephone rings. Tracy turn vaguely, indecisively, and goes to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over her shoulder) Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She disappears into the apartment. O.S. she picks up the  ringing phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she sits with the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous) ...No, I just got in... I don't know  if I can... Listen, I can't talk  now. Can I call you back?... Okay...  Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up the phone, stands and turns back toward the  door. Duncan is standing right behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not from New York, actually. But  I'm very, very far from home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you can't come in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan looks at her for a moment, then looks about the  apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) I thought we might get some coffee.  Can I buy you -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someplace nearby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not tonight. You'd better go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got no place to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious) You can't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just, just a little coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, tomorrow. When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said maybe. I don't know. (beat) Listen, I'm sorry about this  afternoon. I really am. All right?  That was my boyfriend on the phone.  He's coming over. So please leave.  Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan doesn't move. He smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her voice rising) Look, do you want me to call the  cops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) It's okay. It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He backs to the doorway and pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you later... sometime. I  still want to buy you that drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps into the hall. Tracy closes the front door and b it. She turns, leans against it and sighs. Outside the door, Duncan's footsteps move down the hall,  pause, then come back to the door. A moment passes. Then  there is a faint knocking on the door. Tracy doesn't move The knocking comes again, a little louder this time. Trac stands and waits, scarcely breathing. After another long  moment, the footsteps finally move away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car pulls into the parking lot behind the station. Clif and Garber get out and walk into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford and Garber walk down a hallway. Uniformed POLICE walk to and fro around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I don't recognize anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three years is a long time in a place  like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three and a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garber stops at the WATCH COMMANDER'S desk and picks up s paperwork. The WC looks up briefly and sees Clifford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Cliff. Howya doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WC looks down again. Three and a half years mean noth to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't remember the man's name. Garber smiles at him an they continue walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long will you be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends on how lucky I get. (beat) I'll only be coming around once,  maybe twice a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to use your old desk?  Someplace to sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Is it vacant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A. Clifford and Garber appear in the doorway. Clifford en walks up to his old desk, opens some of the drawers -- th are empty -- sits down in his old chair, smiles at Garber B. We see Clifford opening a file cabinet and taking out folder stuffed with notices and reports -- C. Clifford standing beside a Xerox machine running off a copy of something -- D. Clifford standing in a hallway talking to a PATROLMAN. Clifford has a legal pad with him and is jotting somethin down on it as the patrolman speaks -- E. Clifford at his desk, making notes on the legal pad -- F. Garber is at his desk, on the phone, Clifford appears the doorway carrying his legal pad. He waves goodbye to G who nods in response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford questions the DESK CLERK. He shows the clerk a p of Duncan taken some years ago in the mental institution. The clerk shakes his head and starts to hand the picture  back when Clifford motions for him to keep it. As Cliffor leaves, the clerk turns the picture over...

dialogues.speaker: BACK OF PICTURE
dialogues.text: Revealing Clifford's name and phone numbers, and a twenty dollar bill paperclipped to the back of the picture --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Clifford pulls his car up to the curb, then consults h legal pad --

dialogues.speaker: LEGAL PAD
dialogues.text: The top three addresses are crossed out. Clifford underli the fourth --

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Clifford looks up from the pad to a bar he has pulled up front of -- the bar Duncan was in. It bears the address  Clifford has just underlined. Clifford gets out of his ca and walks up to the bar. A "Closed" sign is displayed in window. Clifford knocks on the door. After a moment, Hank opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are only a few CUSTOMERS sitting around, waiting fo their wash. A BUM is stretched out on his back across one the tables like a corpse awaiting autopsy. This is CHEATE A MAINTENANCE MAN in grey work clothes enters from the ba He opens a broom closet, takes out a bucket and mop and r them toward the front of the laundromat. He stops at Chea table and shakes him hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, man, move it out. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheater sits up and starts to pull himself together. An O WOMAN sitting against the wall points down one of the ais of washing machines and says to the maintenance man:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another one down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The maintenance man goes to the end of the aisle and look down into the nook created by the absence of one of the  washing machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nudges at whatever's inside the nook with his foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nudging again) Come on, bright eyes. Wake up. Wake --  Jesus Christ! What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: NOOK
dialogues.text: As Curt Duncan raises his head into the light and looks u at the maintenance man. Overnight, his face has swollen  considerably and a bright yellow and purple discoloring a his bruises has emerged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get hit by a truck or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends over and helps pull Duncan to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the maintenance man guides Duncan to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, man, but you can't stay  in here. Go out to the park, lay in  the sunshine. You'll feel better.  Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan goes out the door. The maintenance man turns and s Cheater stretched out again on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless it! Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls Cheater off the table and pushes him to the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out. Out. Out. Out. Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cheater is pushed out onto the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) All right! All right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He straightens his rags indignantly, then looks at Duncan and grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whaddya say, pardner. I'm dry as a  bone. You got any money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan looks at Cheater distrustfully and shakes his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You neither, huh? (with a laugh) My name is Morgan, but it ain't J.P.  Guess I better go to work. Take 'er  easy now, pardner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheater shuffles off in one direction. Duncan turns and g in the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knock at the front door. After a moment, Tracy comes in the front hallway and, crossing to the door, stubs her to on the open closet door. She swears under her breath and  angrily slams the closet door shut. Then, grabbing her in toe, she hops to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's John Clifford. I'm a private  investigator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A private detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd just like to talk, ask a few  questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got nothing to say about anything  or anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, lady, I can be back in thirty  minutes with a search warrant and a  handful of cops, and I can probably  have you arrested, whether or not  the charges would stick. Now do you  want to let me in and talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a badge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show you a badge when you open  the goddamn door!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy unbolts the door and opens it. Clifford walks right and closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't carry a badge. I'm issued a  license, a piece of paper, and I  left it at home. You're Tracy Fuller?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracy leads him into the living room. They sit. Clifford  gives her a picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you recognize this man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford lets out a sigh of frustration, realizing that t woman will continue to be difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's escaped from the insane asylum.  In 1972, he murdered two children...  broke into a house and found them  asleep in bed. It was a little boy,  five an a half, and a little three- year-old girl. After the coroner's  investigation, their bodies were  taken to the mortuary, where the  undertaker took one look at them and  said he couldn't have their bodies  reconstructed for the funeral without  six days of steady work. Then he  asked what had been the murder weapon,  because looking at the mess in front  of him, he couldn't imagine what had  been used. The coroner told him there  had been no murder weapon. The killer  had used only his hands. (beat) The undertaker went to work and had  them done in four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The picture falls out of Tracy's hands. She is stunned to the point of nausea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely able to say  it) He's been here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan is standing on the sidewalk huddled close to a wal He is looking up at Tracy's apartment building across the street.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Traveling up the wall of the building to the open window Tracy's apartment on the sixth floor. SLOW ZOOM IN:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he'll try to see you  again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He said he had no place  else to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's play it safe. Let's assume  that he will.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Reacting to this possibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you work with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, hesitantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan turns up an alley across the street from Tracy's  apartment building and disappears. Sound over: knocking on a door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford is standing at the door. The "Closed" sign still hangs in the window. The door opens, and Hank sticks his  head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your hours tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No hours. Bar's closed on Mondays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to be open if that's  possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closing the door) No way. Monday's my night off. Come  back tomorr...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford violently pushes the door open. The bartender ba off, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through clenched  teeth) This is tomorrow! Now what are your  hours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garber is sitting behind his desk as Clifford walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) Any luck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come to say goodbye, and thank  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From here on, I go it alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the point of chancing it,  Cliff? We'll let you take the credit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Clifford sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to kill him, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garber leans forward in his chair and stares at Clifford. long moment passes. A button on the lieutenant's phone li up and the intercom buzzes. Garber doesn't even look down it. The button flashes on and off, on and off. Finally it stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The closer I get to this guy, the  more I... It gets to me. I don't  know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd better go on home,  Cliff. You've fallen in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not this time. This is the case  that makes up for a whole career. If  you can't understand it now, you  will in a few years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Garber considers another tack and follows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What part does money play in all  this? Play straight with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford is stunned by the question, but he tries to be  casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) For what I'm being paid, it's not  out of line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's hired you for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clifford glares at his friend and doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cynically) So you're a hitman now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passionately) He murdered two kids in cold blood.  You were there, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garber doesn't have to be reminded of his own feelings. H doesn't pursue the argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could get busted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to use?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy needles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garber nods slowly, considering it a good choice of weapo at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're stretching our friendship,  Cliff. If you blow this at all --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never hear from me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garber looks away for a moment. When he looks back, he ju shrugs his shoulders, "washes his hands".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your time. Do it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need any help preparing for  this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up) I'm ready. I'm just trying to think  where he could be in the meantime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few customers sit quietly minding their own business. A WAITRESS leans near the cash register at one end of the  counter. A transistor radio plays country music blues. Th waitress looks up as somebody enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Duncan. He moves to the counter and sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get mugged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snubbed, the waitress comes back and sets the cup in fron of him. She looks down at the change on the counter. Ther isn't enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee's twenty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan looks up at her resentfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling away the cup) Coffee's twenty-seven cents. Ya got  it or don't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan glares at her. He doesn't have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, buster, one cup. On the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes the cup back to him. Some of the coffee spills onto the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink it and be on your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan slowly reaches for the cup, raises it to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan stops, sets the cup down, pushes it away from him slowly rises from his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan and the waitress stand face to face, shooting dart at each other. Then a MAN sitting two seats away reaches  over and places a quarter on the counter between them.
